greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of skew Dyck paths of semilength n and having k UU's (doublerises) (n >= 1; 0 <= k <= n-1).
comment: A skew Dyck path is a path in the first quadrant which begins at the origin, ends on the x-axis, consists of steps U=(1,1)(up), D=(1,-1)(down) and L=(-1,-1)(left) so that up and left steps do not overlap. The length of a path is defined to be the number of its steps.
link: E. Deutsch, E. Munarini, S. Rinaldi, Skew Dyck paths, J. Stat. Plann. Infer. 140 (8) (2010) 2191-2203.
formula: T(n,k) = A126182(n,n-k), i.e., triangle is mirror image of A126182.
G.f.: G - 1, where G = G(t,z) satisfies G = 1 + tzG^2 + zG - tz.
example: T(3,2)=4 because we have UUUDDD, UUUDLD, UUUDDL and UUUDLL.
maple: T:=proc(n,k) if k=0 then 1 else binomial(n,k)*sum(binomial(k,j)*binomial(n-k+j,j+1),j=0..k)/n fi end: for n from 1 to 11 do seq(T(n,k),k=0..n-1) od; # yields sequence in triangular form
mathematica: Do[G[z_] = 1 + t z G[z]^2 + z G[z] - t z + O[z]^m, {m}];
CoefficientList[#, t]& /@ CoefficientList[G[z], z] // Rest // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 15 2019 *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 30 2007
